metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Union of India

facts.text: The plaintiff is the State of West Bengal, specified in the First Schedule of the Constitution.
By virtue of Article 294 of the Constitution, all property and assets in West Bengal vested in His Majesty for the Government of the Province of Bengal became vested in the State of West Bengal.

State of West Bengal enacted the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 (W.B. 1 of 1954); by notification under the Act, all estates and rights of intermediaries and ryots vested in the State, free from encumbrances, together with rights in the sub-soil, including mines and minerals.
Parliament enacted the Coal Bearing Areas (Acquisition and Development) Act, 1957 (Act XX of 1957), authorising the Union of India to acquire any land or any right in or over land.
Union of India issued notifications dated September 21, 1959 and January 8, 1960, expressing intention to prospect for coal lying within lands vested in the plaintiff.
Disputes arose between plaintiff and defendant as to competence of Parliament to enact the Act and power to acquire property of the plaintiff.
Paragraph 9 of Plaint raised controversy on public purpose of acquisition, but withdrawn at hearing.
Notice under s.80 CPC duly served.
Defendant does not deny factual allegations in Plaint but denies legal contentions on legislative competence.
It is in public interest for planned industrialization; coal production essential; regulation of mines under Union control declared expedient.
National Coal Development Corporation Ltd. intervened due to pending litigation with State of West Bengal.
States of Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Madras, Orissa, Punjab, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh appeared.
Plaint amended to add para 9A: Act does not apply to lands vested in Plaintiff; notifications void.
No issues on facts; controversy depends on interpretation of Constitution and Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether Parliament has legislative competence to enact a law for compulsory acquisition by the Union of land and other properties vested in or owned by the State.
Whether the State of West Bengal is a sovereign authority.
Whether assuming State of West Bengal is sovereign, Parliament is entitled to enact law for compulsory acquisition of its lands and properties.
Whether the Act or any provisions ultra vires Parliament.
Whether Act XX of 1957 on true construction applies to lands vested in or owned by Plaintiff State.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act on true construction does not apply to lands vested in or owned by States; supported by Statement of Objects and Reasons, Preamble.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Statement of Objects and Reasons; Preamble to Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions like proviso to s.9, s.10(2), s.11 exclude State lands; 'any person' in s.8 does not include State.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss.4,7,8,9,10(2),11 of Coal Bearing Areas Act, 1957

petitioner_arguments.text: States sovereign; Parliament not competent to acquire State property under Entry 42 List III.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.294; Entry 42 List III; federal principle

petitioner_arguments.text: No express power like in Australian Constitution; GIA 1935 s.127 implies immunity.
Acquisition would make State property precarious unlike individuals under Art.31.

respondent_arguments.text: Act covers all lands including State-owned; comprehensive language in ss.4,7,9.
Proviso to s.9 implies State lands included, requiring consultation.
Parliament competent under Entry 42 List III; States not sovereign in federal sense.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 42 List III; Art.246(3); Entries 52,54 List I

respondent_arguments.text: Public interest in coal production for industrialization; regulation of mines declared expedient.

court_reasoning.text: Statement of Objects and Reasons cannot cut down generality of statute; only for background.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot use to show legislature did not intend to acquire State rights.

court_reasoning.text: Preamble covers acquisition of unworked lands containing coal, not just rights from leases.
Sections 4,7,9 use 'any land or any rights'; proviso s.9 implies State lands included.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consultation required only if State lands covered.

court_reasoning.text: s.10(2), s.11 apply to lease rights; Act covers all interests including full State ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act intends to acquire all rights in coal-bearing land.

court_reasoning.text: Constitution not true federation; States not sovereign units; sovereignty in people.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No immunity of State property from Union legislation.

court_reasoning.text: Parliament competent under Entry 42 List III for all property; supported by Entries 52,54 List I via declarations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power unrestricted; abuse not ground to deny existence.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents from US, Canada, Australia affirm Union can acquire State property for federal purposes.

holdings.text: On true construction, Coal Bearing Areas Act, 1957 applies to lands vested in or owned by States.
Parliament has legislative competence under Entry 42 List III to enact law for acquisition of State property.
States not sovereign authorities immune from Union acquisition.

precedents_cited.relevance: Origin of immunity of instrumentalities doctrine, rejected.
Rejected immunity; power cannot be denied due to possible abuse.

precedents_cited.case_name: Oklahoma ex rel. Phillips v. Guy F. Atkinson Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Congress can condemn State lands for commerce power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cherokee Nation v. Southern Kansas Railway Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Congress power of eminent domain even in States.
Eminent domain essential to federal functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Attorney-General for British Columbia v. Canadian Pacific Railway
precedents_cited.relevance: Dominion can use provincial Crown lands for federal purposes.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of State property; legislative competence for acquisition; executive powers; federal structure.

statutes_cited.relevance: Acquisition procedure; applies to State lands; vesting in Union or Government company.

statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of estates, sub-soil rights in State.

outcome.summary: The suit by State of West Bengal challenging the Coal Bearing Areas (Acquisition and Development) Act, 1957 as ultra vires and inapplicable to State lands is dismissed. Court holds Act applies to State-owned coal-bearing lands and Parliament competent to enact it under Entry 42 List III read with relevant entries.

key_quotes.text: A statute, as passed by Parliament, is the expression of the collective intention of the legislature as a whole, and any statement made by an individual, albeit a Minister, of the intention and objects of the Act cannot be used to cut down the generality of the words used in the statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits use of Statement of Objects and Reasons.

key_quotes.text: The legal theory on which the Constitution was based was the withdrawal or resumption of all the powers of sovereignty into the people of this country and the distribution of these powers save those withheld from both the Union and the States by reason of the provisions of Part III between the Union and the States.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines basis of Indian federalism; rejects State sovereignty.

key_quotes.text: Parliament which is competent to destroy a State is on account of some assumption as to absolute sovereignty of the State incompetent effectively to acquire by legislation designed for that purpose the property owned by the State for governmental purpose.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms Union power over State property.
